section: 1. TERM OF CONTRACT The Term of this Agreement shall be for a period of [* ****] years and [*****] months commencing the 1st day of September 2004 and terminating the [*****] day of [*****].
explanation: The contract term is not clearly defined due to redactions. The start date is provided, but the duration (number of years and months) and the precise termination date are redacted, making it impossible to determine the exact end date of the agreement. This creates uncertainty about the length of the agreement and the parties' obligations, which can lead to potential disputes regarding the duration of the endorsement rights and compensation.

section: D.Notwithstanding paragraphs 4A, 4B and 4C above, CONSULTANT shall be entitled to endorse and play the [*****]. The parties expressly agree that CONSULTANT may permit [*****] the use of CONSULTANT'S name and/or likeness in [*****] print and/or television advertisement provided that this is executed in a manner consistent with [*****] past [*****] advertising practice using similarly situated professional golfers with competing golf club endorsement agreements that include [*****]. If [*****] use of CONSULTANT varies from past practice of utilizing similarly situated professionals, CONSULTANT will take action to remedy the situation [*****]. If CONSULTANT participates directly in any [*****] sponsored photo shoots for advertising or PR, CONSULTANT shall wear his ADAMS GOLF [*****]. The parties further expressly agree that CONSULTANT'S endorsement of the [*****] shall not include the right to place a [*****] logo on his ADAMS GOLF [*****] or the ADAMS GOLF [*****]. If CONSULTANT'S relationship with [*****] terminates during this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall be permitted to replace the [*****] endorsement with another [*****] endorsement under the same terms and conditions expressed herein.
explanation: This section allows Watson to endorse another product, [*****], despite the exclusivity clause in Section 4, which prevents him from endorsing competing products. The ambiguity arises because the specific product, [*****], is redacted. It is unclear whether [*****] is considered a 'PRODUCT' as defined in the contract (golf clubs) or something else (e.g., apparel, golf balls), making it uncertain whether this endorsement truly violates the exclusivity clause. If [*****] does fall under the definition of PRODUCT, it directly contradicts the exclusivity clause. If not, the redacted nature of [*****] still creates ambiguity regarding what endorsements Watson is actually permitted to make.

section: Notwithstanding any other paragraph of this Agreement, in the event that CONSULTANT dies or is unable to play tour golf at all, ADAMS GOLF may terminate this Agreement on thirty (30) days' written notice. Upon such termination, CONSULTANT and/or CONSULTANT'S estate shall be required to repay ADAMS GOLF for that period of the Agreement not performed by CONSULTANT. The repayment amount shall be calculated in the same way as repayment is calculated under paragraph 8A.
explanation: This clause allows ADAMS GOLF to terminate the agreement if Watson is 'unable to play tour golf at all'. This phrase is ambiguous. It doesn't specify what constitutes 'unable to play'. For example, does a temporary injury qualify? Does it require a permanent disability? This ambiguity allows ADAMS GOLF to potentially terminate the contract under circumstances that are not clearly defined, creating an unfair advantage. Furthermore, the requirement for the estate to repay ADAMS GOLF for the 'period of the Agreement not performed' is arguably unconscionable in the event of death.
